reviewText: I recently was browsing the foreign movie section of my local library and fell upon this early release from the Film Movement catalog of foreign and indie movies. I immediately snapped it up as I outright love Film Movement."Agata and the Storm (2004 release from Italy; 118 min.) brings a multi-character ensemble movie about Agata, a bookshop owner in her mid-to-late 40s, who somehow attracts the attention and eventually the love interest of a younger man, "13 years younger" (comments Agata), to be exact. Meanwhile Agata's brother Gustavo learns that he was adopted at a young age, and hence he's not Agata's "real" brother. There are plenty of other subplots too many to describe here. Will Agata find true love with her younger man? Does Gustavo come to terms with his new family situation? To tell you more of the plot would ruin your viewing experience and you'll just have to see for youself how these questions, and other subplots, will play out.I love foreign movies as much as much about anyone you'll ever find, but I could not really get into this movie for whatever reason. The characters didn't resonate with me, and hence I had no emotional involvement or investment in this movie, despite all the talking and talking and talking. I kept thinking, hope against hope, that it would eventually get better but in the end it just didn't. This is only the second time in seeing dozens and dozens of Film Movement releases that I was disappointed. Maybe it was just me, I don't know.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'd never heard of this film when I rented it so it was all a surprise.  At first I didn't know who the characters were or their relationships.  But that was part of the plot.....a sweet, rather hapless architect discovers that he's not who he thought he was and that send him on an entirely new course in life.  It includes people he probably would never have rubbed shoulders with in his "former" life.  Also, new activities, like bowling and a big white hen!It's a fun, warm-hearted, charming and very colorful film, guaranteed to perk anyone up on a dreary day.  Very Italian!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I LOVE THIS MOVIE!  I rented it originally, and decided I wanted toown it, so I can watch it anytime.  If you enjoyed "Pane e Tulipani"(Bread and Tulips) , you will love this romantic movie!  It is funny,sweet, and wonderful.  Agata owns a book shop, and this story followsher labyrinthine path to love, as well as exploring the story of herbrother on a quest to find his biological family.  Highly recommended!
Title: N/A

reviewText: An Italian classic!  Silvio Soldini is a masterful observer of humanity.  A romantic comedy with tragedy, all characters receive their full due.  And what a beautiful cast.  A bookstore proprietor is wooed by a younger, married man.  An architect is accused of neglecting his wife and son.  He discovers that his real mother is dying and his father is a fraud.  He inherits a new brother.  And Agatha is not his sister... and his new brother loves a woman and still finds time for other sexual pursuits.  You may find this plot complicated but persist.  It all plays out to a very satisfying conclusion.  Warm, amusing, totally winning.  It is very obvious .... Mr. Soldini loves his people.  Not to be missed.
summary: ENTER THE LION'S DEN OF LIFE

reviewText: About a middled aged book store owner Agata who falls for a younger man,her brother finds out a strange thing in the middle that changes all their lives. In spite of death there is comedy like light bulbs blowing out.By American standards it is somewhat racy, but it is a good heartedromance.
summary: Italian version of a romantic comedy

reviewText: We loved Licia Maglietta in Bread and Tulips and wanted to see another film with her lovely presence.  Never got that far.  Within 10 minutes was a graphic sexual sequence.  We shut it off as we do not watch porn, soft or otherwise.  Too bad because we were really enjoying subtitle films.  The rating is crucial for us and we were quite disappointed.
summary: Rate this R for graphic sexual scenes

reviewText: I thought Licia Maglietta was awesome in Bread and Tulips, which I stumbled upon when trying to learn Italian.  I was pleased to find many of the same actors and actresses are in this film.  Italian films have a different mindset compared to most American ones--more true to life and not always with a "sugary ending" as my Mom would say.
